review: Very nice.  Boots very quickly.  Firmware support locked up during update using Kies 3, but Win7 64bit should have been using Kies 2.6, so the whole thing went sideways, halfway.  Tech support call walked me thru a factory-reset of firmware, and the stuck-halfway-update vanished.  Updating to newest firmware using Kies 2.6 worked okay (though all data stored on device was erased).  Overall, very good, would buy another.

This is my review of the Samsung Galaxy Tab 4 10.1. This review is not incentivized by Samsung in any way. I purchased the product for my own use.

What is it?

The Samsung Galaxy Tab 4 is the aforementioned companys latest foray into the midrange tablet market. With these tablets you're not likely to find a retina display or anything over 720p resolution, but they're more reasonably priced, and therefore, more likely to be adopted by more people.

Specifications

Processor: 1.2 GHz Quad Core
Memory: 1.5GB
Storage: 16GB with additional microSD slot
Display: 1280800
Operating System: Android Kit Kat 4.4 with Samsungs TouchWiz UI
As you can see, those specs really aren't too shabby, but they're definitely not bleeding edge technology. However, having the latest and greatest isn't always the best. For example, I recently purchased the higher end Galaxy Tab Pro 12.2 and was utterly disappointed in it. Yes, the screen was beautiful but you could tell that not a lot of games had been properly coded for that resolution as the HD graphics appeared pixelated and blocky. Also, the Tab Pro suffered from massive lag and stuttering when when navigating through the operating system. You can read about my experience with that tablet here. It was promptly returned to Best Buy.

Back to the Galaxy Tab 4.

As mentioned earlier, it runs Kit Kat 4.4 with Samsungs custom TouchWiz user interface over top. In my opinion, this isn't a bad thing since I have never been a fan of HTCs Sense UI. It sadly still comes packed full of bloatware that I almost always remove if possible.

Initial Thoughts

Being an ex-member of the cult of Steve Jobs, I am still getting used to the Android world and the lack of high resolution displays in some products. The Galaxy S5, which I own, has the best display and form factor on the market right now. Are you listening Apple? Thankfully, there are cheaper Android tablets available that still offer a high quality user experience.

Once you go through the obligatory setup screens and sync your applications, the tablet is zippy and runs with no lag whatsoever. Overall memory utilization is low when using several apps at once and multi-tasking.

Display

OK, this is a 720p display. You will notice a difference if using an S5 and then the Galaxy Tab 4  but lets not compare the two. The 1280800 screen is actually quite beautiful and bright. This is one of the brighter screens Ive seen on a midrange tablet. Text is sharp as are the graphics, both are quickly rendered thanks to the 1.5GB RAM and quad core processor. Yes, I think it should be a 1080p panel, but its a $319 tablet.

Performance

I was able to open apps and switch between them fairly quickly. This little tablet is definitely more responsive than its bigger, more expensive brother. Even under heavy use the Tab 4 performed excellent. Its able to handle video encoded to 1080p with no stutter, even though its obviously rendered at 720p on the screen. No complaints at all about performance.

Final Impressions

Im still an Apple fanboy, just now living in an Android world. I really like the Galaxy Tab 4. Its fast, responsive, light, and does what I need it to do. I feel like for the most part, I could ditch my laptop when traveling. That is, as long as Im not running a GoPro, or editing HD video.

The display is not as sharp as I like, but the applications and games I use are not upated to be displayed yet at the higher resolutions on the Tab Pro.

Kit Kat has grown, the OS takes up about 4GB of the internal 16GB, and by the time you add-in the Samsung applications and associated bloatware, you have only about 9GB of usable space. That almost sounds like a Surface tablet, no? LOL Sorry, couldn't resist. Samsung says the answer is to use a microSD card  which you will want to do immediately. They state on their site, that a maximum of 64GB is supported, although I am tempted to buy a 128GB and try it. I know those work in the S5.

So, should you buy it? If you like new gadgets, sure. If you want a great performing Android tablet for a great price, absolutely. I cant really find anything wrong with this little guy. Its a keeper.

UPDATE

I have had 3 samsung tablets, and all of them had issues. All of them had the worse battery performance and the worse bugs I have ever seen. It was so bad, I thought after almost a year of use the battery in the tablet had just gone bad because when ever it dropped to 60%, it'd just shut down. So I went out, bought a new battery, got it all installed and I still had the exact same issue. It isn't the battery. The hardware is absolute trash. Two of my tablets had flickering screens. It's just flicker on and off, I even got one replaced and shortly later, it had the exact same issue. I have formatted this thing so many times in hopes that I could fix the issue, made sure all updates were on and I can not get these tablets to work without flaws. This one and the 2 Samsung 12.2 models that I've had are the exact reason why I will NEVER buy a Samsung or Android based tablet again. I have delt with Lenovo tablets, Asus and multiple standard computers and I have never seen such a terrible product as these. Do not buy these, after dealing with 3 of these tablets, it is safe to say that Samsung makes the worse tablets today. I would rather go with an Apple then invest in one of these again.

Edit: So today I decided to try something out. I thought maybe the tablet was over heating so I pulled apart the back, let the battery hang out and waited to see. I noticed after a little bit the tablet was no longer shutting down at 60ish%. So I went to screw the battery back in, but leave the outer plate off. The moment I put the screws in for the battery trim, the tablet shut down.

The solution to the inadvertent shutdown on these tablets... remove the screws from the battery casing. Ever since I removed mine, the tablet no longer has problems. I am still leaving it with one star since I had to go through so much and make physical changes to the system in order for it to even work. Thanks Samsung.

I bought this tablet two ago to use at school. I use it primarily for controlling my Chromecast, as well as streaming videos, and writing notes in class. The software is more than excellent, and very comfortable to use, even for the most inexperienced of users. However, my primary issue is with the hardware.

Comparing it to the Galaxy Tab 3, it lacks backlit buttons, vibration feedback, and a whole bunch of sensors (the only sensor included is the accelerometer). I've never had any problems with any applications lagging or freezing due to lack of resources, so the memory and processor is pretty decent.

The battery is the only reason why I did not give 4 stars. Within writing this review (no background apps running, and at 30% brightness), I've used about 11% of battery life. I can not expect this battery to last more than 3 hours of continuous use. Last Summer, I once took my tablet out to play Pokemon GO, and I only got about 2 hours of use before it died (probably due to the use of GPS), and it died with 20% of life reporting. I've also noticed that the battery will report false percentages (this is a sign of a faulty battery).

I wouldn't recommend getting this version; if you're looking for higher quality tablets, I would recommend looking at Samsung's newer products.

The apps and controls all work fine and in English.  If you need it, the manual can be downloaded in English (assuming you don't read Korean) via a PDF file.  The vendor also included an electrical adapter so the Korean charger plug can fit into a standard US socket.  Again, no issues.

This tablet has been wonderful. I love the 10 inch screen, the slick interface, and almost everything about this tablet. Previously, I was an Appleite, though I never was a die-hard. I was grandfathered into Apple's tablets and phones from my old-school iPods and then the iPod touch which I used as a wannabe smartphone until I broke down and actually got a smartphone. By then I'd already invested in a bunch of apps on the iTunes store. However, the whole time I kept with Apple, I begrudged the fact that Apple didn't play nicely with Google. I couldn't have control over certain settings and preferences that seemed logical and basic. I couldn't expand my storage (and that 8GB limit always plagued me at the worst times when I wanted to take a picture). Screen replacements on my iPhone 4 were a pain even for me, a decent techie.

Samsung in general has been a nice gateway into the Android realm where many of my grievances with Apple have disappeared. It has an easy interface like Apple. I'm not as constrained as I felt before. I love the expandable storage. I even convinced my even stronger Appleite wife to get an identical tablet, and we've both now left our iPhones for Galaxy phones.

All in all, I've had very few complaints with the tablet. The only reason I knocked it a star was due to some charging overheating problems and overall slow battery charging. The problem ended up majorly being solved by purchasing a new charging cable. However, I was surprised that the tablet didn't have better protection from overheating and rebooting when the charging cable was giving it an inconsistent current or voltage. Also, the battery takes a pretty ridiculous time to charge. This might actually be solved with a new battery. But currently, this tablet (albeit one I purchased used) can't even charge overnight. To fully charge takes 12+ hours sometimes. I tend to fault the used hardware and the likely problematic battery, so I don't complain too much.

All of the games and web pages I have been on thus far ran smoothly without much delay. That is one of the biggest pains in smaller sized electronics, but this tablet is an exception. If you are going to purchase a tablet, not just this one in particular, you should invest in a case with a built in keyboard as it makes using a great deal easier. I have a feeling this tablet will last me a long time because all of the Samsung products I have had consistently met my standards and has been durable. If you are debating on whether to get this tablet or a different one; you should definitely pick the Samsung Galaxy Tab 4.

Lots of people stare at their computer or ipad screens for very long hours.  I don't know about everyone else but my eyes get tired after
long hours on a computer or notebook.  In addition to just turning down the brightness of the screen,  the best remedy to protect my eyes has been to buy Apple products where one can use reverse video, viz. white letters on a black screen rather than black letters on a bright, white screen.  I use google software all the time but I have to stay away from  android laptops and tablets with their  bright, white screens in order to protect my eyes.  Thus far, only Apple builds screens that allow for white letters on a black screen rather than the opposite.  I hope someone at Google or Samsung or ... is listening.
And ... I imagine that reverse video  prolongs battery life.  For Apple users who haven't tried reverse video, the keystroke to use is
Control/Alt/Command8.  That keystroke reverses  black on white to white on black and the opposite as well.

This thing is fantastic. My favorite thing about it, besides for its crystal clear display (and a bunch of the other qualities noted in the item description) is its split screen capability, so now when I write my school essays and paraphrase everything from another source, I no longer have to switch screens, because I can type, see my essay, AND look at what I'm copying--ahem paraphrasing--at the SAME TIME. It's wonderful, really, and saves me lots of switching between screens time (approximately 32.4 seconds per essay).

P.S. I in way condone plagiarism, but I do condone buying the Samsung Galaxy 4 tab and letting it eat your life and personal relationships away like it has mine. You won't regret it!

I received a Galaxy Tab 4 for my birthday as a gift from my mother. Six months later I still enjoy using it every day!

This Android tablet has a beautiful 10.1 inch TFT screen with vivid colors and excellent viewing angles; two features Samsung screens are renowned for. The screen is excellent for web browsing, watching videos and viewing photos. It is comfortable to use for reding text dispite it's modest 1280x800 resolution. The luminosity is great indoors and outdoors. Multiple people are able to view the screen from wide angles without color shifting or other compromise in image quality.

Performance is exceptionally good wether its for playing high end games like CSR Racing or Real Racing 3. There are stereo speakers on the sides of this tablet and the audio quality through them is good for general use. The volume is loud and clear, however the quality resembles laptop speakers. I recommend headphones or a bluetooth headset for high quality audio playback. Web browsing is rendered smoothly, even when loading desktop web pages. The dual band WiFi delivers excellent range and reduces page load times.

The Tab 4 comes with a few pre-installed apps. That considered, I perused the application manager and disabled/Uninstalled features I won't use, just as one can do to a desktop computer to improve the responsiveness beyond that out of the box. Once features like S-Voice (think Siri) and Google search activaton via the home key were disabled responsiveness improved dramatically.

Battery life is a major high point of this tablet. At 50% screen brightness I go through two days of browsing, gaming and other multimedia like video calling and charge on the second day with ~8 hours screen on time. Usage time is increased by manually adjusting the brightness to ambient light levels, but note there is not an ambient light sensor on the Tab 4. Adjusting the brightness to ambient levels, the Tab 4 manages 12 hours screen on time with power saving disabled and all radios/antennas on.

The build and aesthetics are decent, 8/10. The tablet is extremely thin; sometimes it feels too thin to hold without a case, so I keep it in a rubberized case available seperately. It is light enough to hold up and watch movies without getting uncomfortable. The thinness combined with performance of this tablet really gives a high end feel to the overall experience.

I recommend this tablet to anybody looking for a quality, name brand device that performs exceptionally well in daily use that truly delivers in multimedia applications. I am highly stisfied with my Galaxy Tab 4 and don't have any complaints in build quality or performance.

According to reviewers on Amazon, Android 5.01 isn't Google's finest hour.  My experience is that it is unstable. I bought the first one not knowing someone falsely advertised the operating system shipped with device and immediately returned it to Amazon.  I liked Samsung's thin, light weight design and, thinking the screw-up might have been a fluke, I ordered anther one c! aiming to contain Android 4.4.2.  Oh boy... here we go again! I just sent this directly to Samsung:

I bought a Galaxy Tab 4, 10.1 inch tablet (model SM-T530; ser# R52G30X83ZB)last week to replace a 4 year old original galaxy tab.  I use it primarily to listen to music, read and check email. I have an extensive music library and so I purchased a 64 GB micro SD card to store music and personal files.

My initial attempt to transfer from the original tab with a 16 GB micro SD card to the Tab 4 was a disaster.  Many of the MP3 files were empty; WMA files did not play and only about 1/3 of the songs were functional. I put the 16 GB card in the new Tab 4 and it worked fine.

I re-formatted the 64 GB card and started from scratch transferring files from my computer to the new TABs card.  Some of the files worked, some didn't but the WMA files played OK.

That took a few hours.  Then I transferred 25 GB of MP3s.  That took several hours.  They were on the card.  I saw them.  Not all of them worked, probably about 1/3 of the 5000.  About 30 minutes later they were gone, vanished.  No longer on the card.  The folder is empty and I now cannot write, delete, change any files or folders on the card.  I did not write protect the card.

What is going on?  The device is now seemingly worthless for my purposes. I don't necessarily want a refund; I want a device that does what it said it was going to do.

Please advise?

I have been using this tablet for about 10 months now. I personally do not like small screens tablet, so I believe this has a moderate size between phones and laptops. I use it mainly for internet browsing and video streaming form Youtube, Netflix, and Amazon. If you keep the display brightness below 55%, the battery life is really very good. I think it can easily support like 5 hours of continuous video streaming or even more.

The good. This tablet has a very good battery life keeping the brightness in a fair level. It is really fast and responsive with a large screen that is suitable for watching your favorite TV series. The touch experience is also great. Never had any problems with the usability of this tablet.

The bad. One drawback of this device is the camera. I am not a fan of taking or even viewing pictures, but sometimes I need to capture like a piece of paper or a note of some kind to come back to it later. The camera fails me in this case. It is also hard to read bar or QR codes with this camera. Another bad thing in this device is the lack of LTE data plans support (no SIM card). Which means you need to rely on WiFi to connect to the internet.

Overall, I am really happy with this device. I would like to have a better camera and LTE support but not for a much higher price. If you are always within a WiFi range (most of us are these days) and you need a tablet for simple tasks like browsing, reading, streaming, or may be simple text processing, this tablet can completely fulfill your needs.

This tablet was purchased for me by my mom using her Amazon account so this is a verified Amazon purchase. I received it as a Christmas present from my parents last year. At first, I loved it. It wasn't as nice as the iPad (app wise mainly) but for my purposes (games and surfing the web) it was great. Even the price point was better than the iPad. Well fast forward 8+ months, the tablet is worthless!  It started acting up 5 months in with the device overheating and force closing "running" apps. Funny how it would always tell me more apps were running than actually were, lol. This problem occurred sporadically for the next few months. Now it does it every time the device is turned on, within minutes of being on. The battery drains at a rapid pace as well, from a full 100% (device overheats so I restart, hard reset, etc) down to the 30s. Don't even try to use it if the battery is under 75% or you'll be sorry, the battery will start dropping 1% every second until the device turns itself off!  Unfortunately I can't return it to Amazon as it is past the 30 day window though Samsung is willing to fix it free of charge (since it's still under warranty). I'm amazed at how a device so highly rated can have as many problems as mine did, my first gen iPad is still going strong. Luckily for me, Amazon had a great price on the iPad minis so I just ordered one to replace this paperweight. This apple user has yet to be swayed over to the android side if this is what they are offering. I can't recommend it, save your money and buy an iPad. I gave it two stars for the excellent customer service Samsung has, it's hands down the best compared to Apple which is laughable.

NOTE:  I've attached pictures of my error messages.  Notice the time and battery percentages in each picture. The two pics were taken within a minute of each other yet the battery dropped quite a bit!  As they say, the proof is in the pudding, lol.

About 6 weeks ago I started having issues charging the Samsung tablet. A red x appeared over the battery symbol and the tablet appeared to be charging but very slowly. This red x means that the tablet is plugged into a computer and exchanging data but in reality it was plugged into the Samsung AC wall charger using their cable.

I tried another Micro USB charging cable and it worked fine but not every time. I was worried that the charging port on the tablet was going bad. I take excellent care of my smart devices and I wanted to find out what the issue was. I contacted Samsung support using the on line message support system. It took about an hour to convince Samsung that the cable was bad and perhaps the AC wall charger.

They shipped me a new AC wall charger and the cable. I tried only the cable by itself first and it has worked perfectly every time I haved plugged it in for three weeks. I wanted to post this update in case any other user of this tablet is having a similar problem. Good luck with Samsung support as the person I dealt with was stubborn about recognizing that one of their products was defective.

---------------------

I own a lot of different tablets but this is my first Samsung and let me say that I am impressed. I went to the store to buy a 7 inch unit but quickly decided to upgrade to the 8 inch version. There were several features that I was concerned about and the 8 inch unit just fit my needs better.

* Larger screen size for reading
* More basic internal memory at 16 GIG versus 8 GIG for the 7 inch unit
* The ability to upgrade to a 64 GIG SD card instead of just 32 GIG - note: It actually will use a 128 GIG SD card. I used a Sandisk Class 10 card at 128 GIG. It is great for storage, books, apps, music and videos.

Just remember that in my experience your need for more memory grows as you use your tablet more and if you buy a smaller memory upgrade capability you may regret it. The price difference on launch day was only $40 more. I already own 8 tablets in my family so my experience has proven this need for more memory. As you add more books and more apps the memory slowly gets eaten up. I went ahead and also purchased a Samsung 64 GIG Micro SD memory card and I got a Class 10 Pro series at a cost of $55. It reads at 70 MB/s and a write speed of 20 MB/s. For under $300 you will have a powerful tablet that has more memory (80 GIG) than a 64 GIG iPad Mini for a much lower price.

Here is the link to the Samsung Memory that I purchased:

Samsung 64GB MicroSD XC Pro Class 10 UHS-1 Read Speed 70mb/s Write Speed 20mb/s MB-MGCGB Ultra Fast Speed Memory Card with SoCal Trade, Inc. Memory Card Reader

Some other key features are:

* A powerful Qualcomm quad core CPU operating at 1.2 GHZ ( You can see the speed in using the tablet)
* 1280 by 800 pixel display
* A 3 MP rear facing camera
* A 1.3 MP front facing camera
* It weighs in at 11  ounces per my scales
* Bluetooth 4.0
* Internal 16 GIG of flash memory and it goes to 80 GIG using a 64 GIG Micro SD card (Use a high quality Class 10 Micro SD card)
* 1.5 GIG of internal RAM
* A 4450 mAh internal battery pack
* Android 4.4 operating system Kit Kat
* 1080P playback and recording
* A built in IR blaster to control your TV and other infra-red devices and an App called WatchON the help you control your TV and see what is playing on your cable service.
* The tablet comes with a 31 inch charging and data cable that is a Micro USB on one end and a USB on the other.
* It comes with an AC wall charger that outputs 5 VDC at 1 Amp and it will operate on 100 to 240 VAC and 50/60 HZ.
* It features a power multitasking function that lets you see and use two apps simultaneously which is something that an Apple iPad cannot do. Very nice feature!
* You can set up multiple users and limit the apps that they can see and use.
* You can set up a child friendly and protected user interface.
* You get $300 worth of free content

I found this tablet to be extremely versatile and very fast. The quad core processor is very impressive and browsing the internet was fast and easy. Adding my Gmail account to the tablet literally took a minute. I put together a video to show you the locations for the controls and what the tablet looks like. It is a bit long and I couldn't even talk about all of the items that I wanted to include. I apologize for the length of the video but I get excited over good technology. Overall the tablet is impressive and it is well worth the money based on the quality and performance that I have seen. I rate it as a 5 star item.

* A $10 credit on the Google Play Store
* 3 months free of Hulu plus
* 1 year free of Boingo WIFI
* 50 GIG of free Drop Box cloud storage for 2 years
* Sirius 3 months free
* 3 free audible books for new members
* 3 digital magazines free on Zinio for 2 months
* A free Polaris Office

Update May 2, 2014:

Last night I installed the Amazon AppStore and the Amazon Kindle reading app. I down loaded over 950 books and I was blown away by the speed of the downloads. The CPU and strong WIFI connection really shines with its speed. I was using a strong 2.4 GHz WIFI and I downloaded the speedtest app from Google Play and I could download data at 13.36 Mbps and upload data at 2.09 Mbps. Since I am on ATT Uverse that is a reasonable result. The tablet can use either a 2.4 GHz or a 5 GHz WIFI channel. On the 5GHz frequency I got 17.71 Mbps download and 2.24 Mbps upload.

I used the Amazon AppStore as I own over 1000 apps and it was fast and easy to download many of them. I could transfer them to the SD card to conserve my internal memory. I had to do this manually on some of the apps and others went to the SD card automatically.

The sound of the speaker is pretty loud for its size. I paired the tablet with a Bluetooth speaker and the process is fast and easy. I use Bluetooth a lot and I was glad to see it work so well and Bluetooth 4.0 is the low power version to help reduce battery consumption.

Over three hours of continuous work the battery dropped from 98% to 62% which is pretty good considering I downloaded over 950 books and 35 apps. I love the fact that I can use my Amazon books and apps so easily and still have access to the Google Play Store to download utilities and apps that are not available on Amazon. It is like having the best of both worlds.

Photographs are easy to take and edit. I even shot some videos. I wanted to include some in my online video but there was not enough space and time remaining to do so.

Using an app called Hangouts I was able to do face to face video calls and text messaging with my wife using our gmail account emails. The quality was as good as Facetime and the connection worked very well. I had to install the app Hangouts on my wife's iPhone 5S and the app is free on iTunes. The app was already installed on my Samsung Galaxy Tab 4.

I continue to be impressed with the performance and capability of this tablet.

I did want to add that the case is slippery and a little wide to hold so I suggest that you get a case to improve your ability to grip the tablet and hold it.

The amount of issues I've had with this definitely outweigh the positives. I had a Tab 3 that had problems but figured I'd try out the 4 thinking it would be better and apparently I was wrong. The size is great, it's sturdy (when it falls it doesn't crack), the resolution is good and the system itself is pretty good. The battery is horrendous, I have a Galaxy S5 which I use just as much and my tablet will be on 10% in about an hour while my phone is still on around 80% at minimum. There is constantly an issue with the charging port as well, either the charger itself is going (they don't last long at all, they're constantly breaking) or something inside the port itself breaks, which is the issue I had with the Tab 3. Right now I'm having the issue where I plug the tablet in and even though it's plugged in and charging, the tablet shuts off anyway and dies.
All in all, I don't feel like it's worth the money. Might have to go to an iPad the next time, makes me wonder if they're so expensive because they work better.

Updated review (August 9, 2015)  I love this tablet so much that I now own TWO Samsung Galaxy Tab 4 10.1 tablets (first one I purchased I keep in my bedroom and use it daily instead of my bulky laptop)! The first one has Lollipop from a late June, 2015 OTA Update. Regarding my second Tab 4 10.1...August 9, 2015, just received my OTA Lollipop, so both tablets have Lollipop!

Second Tab 4 10.1 (I use this ALL THE TIME in my Kitchen), and it is so peppy with Lollipop, saves some on battery and the Lollipop is much improved over KitKat. If you buy the Tab 4 10.1, it may take you a few days for you to receive Lollipop. Go to Settings, General tab, About device, Updates, press auto update, and then update and it will check to see if your uodate is ready, be sure you want it because when you update, no going back...the uodate takes about 40 minutes to complete and you need at least 75 percent battery or higher.

PROS/SPECIAL FEATURES I FOUND WHILE TESTING THIS TABLET:

+ Size - This Tab 4 10.1 is perfect watching videos, pictures and movies. What I do to carry it around is to place it in a large backpack or in a large tote purse. **The advantage is that now I do not have to carry my laptop with me when I travel anymore. I purchased a small and portable Bluetooth keyboard so I can type easilythis also fits into my backpack for travel. Saves weight and I type just like I am on my laptop at home.

+ Lollipop Update and More The tablet I find is quite responsive and peppy with no lagging. The Lollipop runs this tablet wonderfullyYes, I updated this to Lollipop in June, 2015 (it came with KitKat). Since the update, it runs smoother with no lagging whatsoever. I made sure that I updated ALL my personal apps BEFORE I updated so they are Lollipop ready!
About updating to Lollipop: Be sure you want to do this as once you update, you cannot go back to KitKat. Also, for best results before you update the OS (I found this to be true), be sure to update your Apps from the Playstore to the newest updates. This is so your apps will be Lollipop ready and they will work well. And also be sure that your battery has at least 75 to 80 percent of battery left as the update will take about 45 or more minutes to complete and then your tablet will need to restart and reset the apps etc.

+  Clear and Vivid Screen Resolution, Brightness and Other Info  It is true that this is the highest resolution, yet in my opinion, I find the colors vivid, pictures and text sharp! Watching videos and movies on this I find very clear

+ Battery life/Speed  Very good battery life! For me, I have found that I am constantly on WiFi (Internet). However, I also find that this tablet gets me at least 1 to 2 hours MORE daily than my older Tab 3 10.1 did!

+ WiFi Connecting/Speed of WiFi and MORE -  This tablet connects SUPER quickly to my home WiFi and has never ever dropped the WiFi signal no matter where I am in my home. WiFi is VERY STRONG using this device, even when I am very far from my router I still have 4.5 bars! *** To test the speed and strength of this WiFi and compare it to my other Android devices, I went to the Playstore and got the free app called WiFi Analyzer. This is a MUST HAVE app for any Android device as it gives you a visual report on the WiFi strength of your tablet, phone etc.

+ SPECIAL INFO about INTERNET CONNECTION - Yes, this is a WiFi only, but when you are away from an WiFi internet hotspot location, there are ways to can get onto the internet such as MiFi and there are ways that you can purchase equipment so that you can have data when you do not have a WiFi hotspot available.

+ Internet & Webpage & Video Viewing - The stock browser does a wonderful job and it opens up webpages very fast. Also I tried Maxthon Browser and this worked very well yet I still prefer the Internet App. Also, I tried out the factory installed Chrome Browser and liked it OK, yet again, I went back the the stock Internet App (this is my preference). Note that the Playstore has many very good (FREE) internet browsers as Dolphin, Opera and many more!

+ EXTERNAL SLOT FOR MICRO SD CARD. This is a must for me as I keep my personal files, photos, and music on my internal SD card. I installed a SanDisk 32GB SD card and it works great on this tablet and I placed my music and files on it and have plenty of space left.

+ Camera / Video Camera  OK camera for a tabletI took this out on a trip and videoed and took some pictures inside and outside. Inside videos and pictures had good lighting and the pictures were quite clear! I am amazed because I forgot to bring my regular digital camera and I was very pleased with the videos and the still pictures. Hint: This tablet has NO FLASH so be sure that inside and outside shots have adequate lighting. Outdoors be sure to take a picture where there is NO GLARE. I took my time and did that and believe it or not, these pictures were some of the BEST ones that I ever took as I held the tablet firm (no shaking) and the colors and sharpness were wonderful However, I found that I use my digital camera for serious picture taking.

+ Home Videos - The stock video player is OK and plays MOST home videos, however, may I suggest QQ Player (Free App from Playstore and the ONLY one I recommend as it plays every home video I tried).

+ Music Player/Sound Quality - This model has the regular MUSIC App, which plays by playlists, songs, albums and even folders. Also there is Google Music app is pre-installed in this tablet and does a fine job. However, I installed the FREE app called Rocket Player from the Playstore and love this music player! As for sound quality - The best way to really enjoy music is through a high quality Bluetooth speaker or Bluetooth headset as the sound quality is superb this way and you can walk about your home listening to your music!

+ OTG USB Compatible (On the Go USB Micro Adapter) - You will need to purchase a OTG (On the Go) Micro USB adapter (Amazon sells them and the cost is under 20 dollars in most cases, just type in OTG Micro Adapter in the search-box for a list of them). This will allow you to plug in your mouse, Flash Drive to the adapter on the large end and plug the small Micro end into the USB port on the Samsung tablet. Then you just plug in your flash drive and you can copy files to the flash drive so easily or view files that are on the flash drive. *Note that portable external hard drives and portable DVD/CD drives will not work using OTG in this tablet because they require a lot of power.

--- ONE MINOR CON - The USB charging port is located at the bottom of the tablet. What this means is that when I want to keep charging the tablet and use it as well and place it on my tablet stand I bought, it will not work right side up in LANDSCAPE MODE.
However, there is a perfect fix for this: I simply place the tablet in LANDSCAPE UPSIDE DOWN with the USB Port ON TOP and then I place it into the stand for table top viewing! This is possible because of the auto rotation!
Also, my MoKo cover/case has a hole for the USB port so I keep it in this and can charge it overnight when the stand is closed. But in this stand, to keep the tablet in the stand to view it, I have to take the USB charger cable out while I am viewing this say in a coffee shop, hotel etc.
I rate this 4.9 stars rounded off to 5 stars because of this minor con.

Bottom line- Would I buy this tablet all over again? Yes, and I liked it so much that I bought a second one to keep on my Kitchen Island area to use to read my recipes, check weather, music and more! This is still my favorite tablet!

I have owned this tablet for four months. Seemed OK at first. It became slower and slower over time and then finally very problematic. As I have now learned, the problems I have had are quite common and not easily fixed. The tablet started having errors, pop-up error messages, stating, to name a few, Unfortunately, Google Play Services has stopped working, Unfortunately, internet has stopped working, Unfortunately, google.apps...  has stopped working, etc. Unfortunately is right! Especially when I received so many of these error pop-ups that I couldn't clear them fast enough to actually use the tablet. After a few days of this happening consistently, the damned tablet started loading up and then powered itself off. It wouldn't stay off though. It would constantly restart, load up again then power off again. Sometimes it would boot-loop and I would have to hard reset it to get it to stay off. That worked to keep it powered off for only a short time before that quit working. I had to let it run itself out of battery power just to shut it down. Followed some tech advice I found after searching the net and thought maybe I could finally use the tablet again but NO! After doing a factory reset and wiping the tablet clean, which you'd think would resolve the error issues, I not only lost all my data and it took an act of God to get it to factory wipe but when it booted up I couldn't get past the friggin' START screen because of all of the same error pop-ups again. Better known as BRICKED. Ugh!

Spend the extra money on a Tab Pro or a Note and save yourself the frustration and stress of having to deal with this Piece of Sh*t. Samsung Customer Service is a joke. 30 day warranty? Think about it. Most electronics work well for that long. Problems usually occur after the first month and if they do, and they will, you're screwed. To pay to have Samsung look at it or the $75 I was quoted to have a local geek service it really isn't worth doing. It makes more sense at this point to spend the money on a higher quality tablet then take a chance on spending the money to have it serviced, hoping it can be fixed mind you, and then dealing with more issues down the road. Do a Google search on the Galaxy Tab 4 10.1 repair and see for yourself how many folks have had issues. The Galaxy Tab 4 10.1 is well known for a myriad of problems.

I hope this review saves others from wasting money on a tablet that won't last  but will surely cause many headaches and a f*ck ton of stress.

After going from an ASUS Transformer with a keyboard dock to this tablet, I was expecting to be disappointed with the battery life.

I played SimCity BuildIt for about three hours straight the other night and brought it down to only about 40%. I once had a marathon fiction-writing session with my Bluetooth keyboard that probably lasted six hours, and the battery never went below 50%.

Actually, though I haven't been trying hard, I haven't yet managed to run the battery all the way down.

Image quality is good, though it suffers somewhat from a lower resolution; I knew that going in, though, so no points off for that.

When I got this tablet it was on sale on Amazon for $270 and it is well worth the price you have tablets that don't even come close and sell for about the same as this tablet. I have only found one issue that I have with this tablet and that is the storage. I am very computer/tablet literate and have no problems with any other devices that I have but with this particular tablet if I move something to my sd card it still shows up in my files on my tablet and then if I delete it from the tablet it mysteriously gets deleted from the SD card too. I have tried everything from specifically naming folders on the SD card and manually transferring them over there and still for some reason if it is on the tablet and I delete them they disappear from my sd card as well (and vice versa if its on my SD card and I delete it from that it deletes it from my tablet as well). I'm sure there might be a simple solution to this and I'll figure it but for right now the file storage between the tablet and the SD card is a little murky so just to be safe make sure you back up any important files on a second device.  I would definitely still recommend this tablet it has too many great perks for that one issue to bring it down. I would also just like to mention to all of those readers out there as much as I love my Kindle I have to admit that with this tablet the Kindle app actually makes reading better than the actual Kindle device so if you're a reader you would probably really enjoy the size of the screen and the functionality of the Kindle Reading App and other reading apps if use them because I also use cool reader  it is really just a very good tablet for reading on.

Let me start by saying,  I did not purchased my tablet from Amazon; it was a birthday gift. My husband purchased it from Sam's Club.  I paid $30 more, because I wanted it the  same day.  That's how eager I was to have this tablet. However,  I do love this tablet.  I have a Note 3 (phone) and it looks exactly like my phone but much larger.  NOTE: it does not have a S Pen. However, it does almost  everything my phone does, but I must say the camera suck on this tablet. I wish there was a better camera on this tablet. I'm also finding that there are a few apps that are not compatible with my device.  Overall,  I do use my tablet more than my phone.  I can send text messages, and make calls using my tablet,  my Bluetooth,  and an app called Mighty Text (which is found in Google Play Market). With that being said,  I pretty much use my tablet all day.  The downside,  it takes several hours to fully charge, meaning it charges slowly.  4 to 5 hours give or take,  for a full charge. Even though it is still functional while it's charging, the time factor can be still be annoying. Also the charger cord included,  is very short. So I ended up purchasing a longer cord. I've noticed that few people have complained about the battery life,  I can't say anything negative. I use mine all day,  without it dying,  if I charge it the night before.  I also allow my battery to cycle; by allowing it to die completely before recharging. Then allowing it to recharge fully, before using.  This helps extend your battery life, and allows your device to check for updates.

I am in love with this tablet. I upgraded from a nook hd.

I think it's perfect in every way a tablet is designed to be and love it. I gave it a 4, when it might have needed a 5, because I am a bit disappointed in how some of the apps work, but I think that's simply because it's a tablet. FB does not have the full capacities it does on my computer, for example. But I know that's an app issue, not a Galaxy issue. Also, figuring out how the photo management works is a bit tricky. I'm sure I'll get it eventually, but I was hoping I might be able to replace my laptop with it, eventually. I love the games I have downloaded on it and use it more for them than anything else, though I do occasionally take a pic with it, when I need to. I've inadvertently deleted some that mattered though, so don't depend on it. I love listening to Pandora on it and love the bluetooth feature. So, for me, I mainly use it for music and games. I don't like the fact that I have to "turn it back on" with the button when it goes into sleep. I would rather just have to touch the screen. I did go on and buy the more expensive Otter casing to protect it, which I am glad I did. Just sorry I felt the need to. That was an additional $60, so it can get really pricey.

I have had the Samsung Galaxy Tab 4 since end of February now and still do not like it any better than when I first got it.  Sure wished I had returned it before the 30 days were up.  However during that time I underwent intensive back surgery and it sort of knocked me down for awhile.  In fact that is why I finally went ahead and ordered the Tablet since my wife and kids had put the money in my Amazon account months ago (Christmas and birthday end of Nov.) for me to use.  Thought it would be good to have this Tablet while I was in the hospital and not have to carry our large laptop.
It is just NOT as easy to navigate with the Tablet to sites like is is on a regular computer.  For instance I wanted to look up something on WebMd and for each subject you'd like to look up you have to use a totally different App whereas on a computer you have it all on WebMD's homepage at your fingertips.  Guess I'll give this Tablet to our Grandchildren and get myself the smaller screen laptop like I should have gotten in the first place.  But have learned a variable lesson in not ordering things such as this from online but going to a local store and then I can return the item much easier and time would not run out on me.
Maybe some of you oldsters out there are more savvy than me (age 72) but normally I pick up on new electronic devices easier than this Galaxy 4 10.1 Tablet has been.  But then even what I have learned to do on it just do not like it's layout at all.
Now I am STUCK with it.

I absolutely love this tablet. It does everything I need it to do and it's the perfect size for watching videos, sending/checking emails, and keeping up with class assignments. I'm so glad that I purchased the Galaxy Tab 4 instead of buying another iPad. My iPad 3 totally stopped working after 3 years. It would not update or restore and is still stuck in recovery mode. I'm also glad that all of the applications I have on my Galaxy S 5 appeared on my tablet after signing in and I didn't have to download them. I'm very happy with my purchase.
This is the finest tablet that I've purchased. Its ease of use and various features are better than expected and exceeded my expectations.

This tablet was a gift for my daughter and she is pleased with it.  She indicates that it is easy to use and large enough to read clearly.  It has enough memory for her tasks.  She no longer has to depend on her telephone for her e-mail and other business duties.

I bought the Galaxy Tab as my old iPad was getting "full" and the cost of obtaining one of larger capacity was almost double what I spent for the Samsung.  The tablet, and a 64 gig memory card both were right around half the price of a 64 gig iPad.

I'm very pleased with the Samsung.  The screen resolution is not as great as the iPad, but it's good enough so that I don't notice for anything I do.
WiFi connectivity is better than the iPad; I use it at work at a major university while I'm in my patrol car, and I can get more hot-spots than ever I could with the iPad.
All the same apps I had for the iPad seem to be available for Android and work just as well.  I put Kindle on it and can't tell the difference between the two devices.

Only a couple of very minor complaints...  The volume control on the edge is very small and hard to feel properly.  The widescreen display means that some sites (notoriously TV guide) won't show quite right... You only get two hours of the "grid" instead of three...

There are not quite the number of high quality apps in some areas.  For instance, I have an iRig and a guitar-amp emulator on the iPad, and no such device is yet available for Android.  (that I'm aware of)
Also, the charging mini-usb port is VERY mini.  Dunno why they didn't use the bigger one.

All in all, a bargain.
I love it. I should have bought the LTE even if it's more expensive.

For years, I have owned Samsung Tablets and phones and love the quality and features. This is my favorite Samsung tablet yet! So far I have had a truly WOW experience using this tablet as it has exceeded my expectations! Below are the Pros and the Cons of this tablet...In late July, 2015, the tablet updated to Lollipop and it saves me battery, love this update.

PROS/SPECIAL FEATURES:

+ Screen Resolution/Weight/Size etc - The first thing I noticed is that this tablet has 149 PPI-Pixels----however, what I discovered is that the screen is very, very clear and the colors are spectacular! The screen is absolutely beautiful! RESULT for me: It is that much clearer and vivid screen than I thought it would be with truly amazing clarity!
**Brightness of the screen: I compared this with my older ASUS MeMopad and found that this screen is MUCH BRIGHTER! (I like a bright and vivid screen and this tablet has just what I was searching for in a screen).

+ Clarity of the screen for reading - It is very easy to read Kindle books and eBooks on this tablet. And I place the tablet inside my case/stand and read in landscape, it is very easy to read on it this way. The tablet just sits in my lap for easy reading.

+ Weight - Lighter than I thought!  For a 10.1 tablet, I found it easy to hold and use.  *Also, I purchased on Amazon a JETech Slim Fit Case and it is an excellent stand/cover and protects the tablet yet lightweight.

+ Speed of this unit / Memory etc - This tablet has adequate memory and I found it enough to keep the tablet running at a good speed. And I found that the tablet runs plenty fast with no lagging.

+ WiFi Connecting/Speed of WiFi and MORE - This tablet connects very quickly to my home WiFi and has never ever dropped the WIFi signal no matter where I am in my home. WiFi is VERY STRONG using this device, even when I am very far from my router I still have 4.5 bars! *** To test the speed and strength of this WiFi and compare it to my other Android devices, I went to the Playstore and got the free app called WiFi Analyzer. This is a MUST HAVE app for any Android device as it gives you a visual report on the WiFi strength of your tablet, phone etc.

+ SPECIAL INFO about INTERNET CONNECTION - Yes, this is a WiFi only, but when you are away from an WiFi internet hotspot location, there are ways to can get onto the internet such as MiFi and there are ways that you can purchase equipment so that you can have data when you do not have a WiFi hotspot available.

+ Internet & Webpage & Video Viewing - The stock browser does a wonderful job and it opens up webpages very fast. Also I tried Maxthon Browser and this worked very well yet I still prefer the Internet App. Also, I tried out the factory installed Chrome Browser and liked it OK, yet again, I went back the the stock Internet App (this is my preference). Note that the Playstore has many very good (FREE) internet browsers as Dolphin, Opera and many more!

+ EXTERNAL SLOT FOR MICRO SD CARD up to 64GB This is a must for me as I keep my personal files, photos, and music on my internal SD card. Note that this was one of the deciding factors that sold me on this tablet. I installed a SanDisk 32GB SD card and it works great on this tablet.

- Camera / Video Camera - The camera is now 3.5 MP which I found took OK pictures, but since it does not have a flash on it, I had to be in very bright lighting. For me, I found that I use my digital camera for serious picture taking. Videos were somewhat grainy on this tablet. (The camera and Video camera are not that great in this tablet)! I rarely use this camera as I prefer to use my Nikon digital camera for my overall picture takingthe camera on this tablet is OK for backup camera, taking pictures to send in an email, etc). Do not expect the camera on this tablet to replace your digital camera.

+ Home Videos - The stock video player is OK and plays MOST home videos, however, may I suggest QQ Player (Free App from Playstore and the ONLY one I recommend as it plays every home video I tried).

+ Reading/Creating/Editing Word, Excel, Text Files and much more on this tablet: This comes with a So So Office app (viewer) for reading Office documents, however, I STILL prefer Kingsoft Office which is a free app from Playstore. It is the best I have ever tried and I am very picky about so called Office programs. It is very compatible with MS Office as it reads, edits and creates Office files and reads PDF files, and it has more features of any other Android Office program that I tried. This app is a MUST have for tablet owners in my opinion.

+ Music Player/Sound Quality  This model has the regular MUSIC App, which plays by playlists, songs, albums and even folders. Also there is Google Music app is pre-installed in this tablet and does a fine job. However, I installed the FREE app called Rocket Player from the Playstore and love this music player! As for sound quality - The best way to really enjoy music is through a high quality Bluetooth speaker or Bluetooth headset as the sound quality is superb this way and you can walk about your home listening to your music!

+ Battery Life- Very good to excellent. Since I have done a few tweaks on this tablet, now I have found that my battery life is better than the first and even the second day. In fact, the battery life now I find that when I use WiFi just when I need it, I now get about 7 to 8 hours with it(this reflects 100 percent brightness however).

***Where battery life is concerned: To make your battery last as long as possible is to be sure to turn off BLUETOOTH AND WIFI when you do not need these. Both are these are memory hogs! Also, I turn off my GPS and even SYNC sometimes to conserve battery and then turn them on later.

+ OTG USB Compatible - This tablet comes with a free OTG On the Go adapter cable. Just plug in your flash drive and you can copy files to the flash drive so easily or view files that are on the flash drive. *Note that portable external hard drives and portable DVD/CD drives will not work using OTG in this tablet because they require a lot of power.

- No support for Flash Videos - Adobe does not support flash in any Android tablets this days. This non support is for all Android tablets, not just Samsung tablets. + Watching Flash Videos - This device does not come with installed flash, however, I found a workaround to solve this. So if you request it in the comments, I will send you instructions on how to installed Archived Flash so you can watch flash videos and what proper browsers I recommend for this tablet...The only browser that I could get the Archived Flash to play on and well was Puffin Browser for 2.99 in the Playstore. (I tried Maxthon, FoxFire Beta and more and this was the only one that played consistently flash videos).
**Here is what I do to watch videos: I use free Playstore apps as YouTube, Netflix, CBS.COM and more and open up the app instead of going to the browser to watch videos that I want to. They play fine in an APP rather than in a Browser.

- No installed Adobe Flash (This can be fixed by installing an Archived Adobe Flash from Adobe website. And I did so and now I can watch flash videos using Puffin Paid browser. (No new Android tablets or phones come with flash, but the Archived Adobe Flash can be installed). Most flash videos play OK with this older Archived Flash, with the exception of Amazon videos (as of March 30, 2014).
-
- Would I purchase this tablet again? YES! In a heartbeat because it is a low cost yet feature packed tablet. And I recommend this to anyone buying their first tablet - this tablet is reasonable in cost, yet it is a really great tablet!
My true star rating is 4.6 stars as I find that this tablet, for the most part, has exceeded my expectations. I did take a small amount of the stars off because sometimes the temperature rises a bit when I install several apps, play games, etc.

If you have questions about this tablet, I will be happy to answer any questions you may have through the comment section.

Tablet experiences thus far(just to lay groundwork for my opinion):

Asus tf700 -  Beautiful screen,nice keyboard,great looking product. Had it for over a yr. Unpredictable. Never knew what it would do from one day to the next. To much work to maintain. Clear out the memory w/cold reboot weekly,shut down background apps to conserve operating memory,check device forum for solution to latest problem(which everyone with the tablet seems to be having,by the way). Beautiful screen resolution, just way too much work. NO MORE ASUS PRODUCTS.

Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7" - Actually, not a bad tablet. Bought it used as a platform for my 2nd coc acct. Screen resolution wasn't that great but it worked. All the time. No glitches. No problems. Still works. Just doesn't look great beside newer tablets.

Galaxy Tab 3  8.0 - Refurbished. Have had it for 4 mos. This could be the perfect size for the casual user. High ppi for this size tabet. Excellent screen resolution. No glitches. It just works without major issues. The battery usage is high. Stick the "Active applications" widget on the home page to cut off background apps. It will give you more battery life. A good deal so far.

Lenovo a8 8" - Solid performer, looks good, strange page setup. Had to install nova launcher to make sense of the layout. Very affordable. Not so great screen resolution. A deal breaker on this one.

So....sold the Asus tf700, the Lenovo a8 and some other stuff thru amazon and bought the Galaxy Tab 4. Pleasantly surprised. A descent screen resolution that looks sharp with everything. Doesn't look as good with CoC as the 8 inch tab 3 but not a deal breaker( more ppi on the 8 inch). I am satisfied with the screen and the tab performance thus far. I am enjoying the larger size. My wife has the Tab S. Exceptional screen res. No operating memory and gets warm. Fast. For my purposes, the Tab 4 10.1 is not perfect, but pretty darn close. No operating issues thus far. Smooth and steady. Turn it on and it works. That's more important for me than a beautiful screen and 100.00 to 200.00 more cost.

The wife loves it. The size is great she watches hulu, Netflix and YouTube. Plus, being able to sync to her phone. The feel and quality of the tab is great. The shipping was great, came in a day before valentine's day which was the shipping date and made me look like the hero.
Has everything I needed. Plays 1080p movies like a breeze and is really fast.  A cheaper alternative to buying that expensive samsung galaxy tab 4 S

THE PROS:
Very clear and sharp screen. Great for playing movies, Youtube videos, etc on. The sound quality is excellent. The unit has yet to crash or reboot itself. And it has a decent battery life. I only have to charge one or twice per week even if I leave it on all the time.

THE ONE CON:  --  (This more aimed at the bone heads at Google, the authors of the android system, rather than Samsung.)
Why can't I write to my micro-SD card while its mounted in the tablet? This makes this a pain in the neck when it comes to storing my music files and pdf book on the sd-card. I have to take it out of the tablet, mount it with my desk top computer -- Debian Linux -- and then re-insert it back into the tablet. Could you please fix this. What you are doing now is more of a 'band-aid'. Also why won't android recognize sd-cards formatted in the ext2 file system? (ext2 is the standard Linux file system) Android is based on Linux isn't it?

my next tab will definitely be a note pro 12, or a future version in that series ( the note devices are simply without compare ), but for my first serious tablet investment, i am well pleased with this purchase ( sidesync has helped these impressions immensely ).

This is my first tablet, so I can't compare it to other models, but I like it a lot.  Finally, I get to join all the people sitting around swiping their fingers on little screens instead of interacting with each other--hello new century!  Seriously, it does all sorts of interesting things, most of which my children haven't explained yet, but the learning curve hasn't been too bad. For the most part, the controls are simple and intuitive. I added a cheap memory card--64gb--so there's a ton of carrying capacity for docs, music, pictures, video.  I really like the solid feel of the device--it has a nice heft to it, without being heavy.  Sold. Right. It worked perfectly right out of the box, and continues to do so.  Plus, I got this baby from Amazon for about $220 bucks new, on a black friday deal--so it packs a lot of bang for that buck.  I'd buy it again, and I'd recommend it to others.

Let me start by saying that I already owned a Galaxy Tab 3 8.0.  It's great. When I found the Tab 4 10.1 super cheap on a Black Friday deal, I thought the bigger screen would be a nice upgrade. And there's the problem. It's not an upgrade.  It's my own fault. I should have checked the specs closer.  The bigger screen would be nice, but it's the same resolution as my 8 inch Tab 3. Since it's stretched out on a bigger screen, things are noticeably not as sharp. The camera is only 3MP vs my Tab 3's 5MP.  There are lots of other differences too, but my point is that you should do some comparison shopping first. For the price, this isn't a bad tablet, but it's not great either. If you have a Galaxy S3, 4, or 5 phone, this is going to feel like a big step down from your phone, and I wouldn't recommend it.

I love this Samsung tab 4 & this is my first tab & it took me 2 months to make up my mind. I have a iPhone and I love it but I thought I need a change & so I need 3 months  to give you a better review.

The display is very nice.  The menus are fairly intuitive. I don't use it as a camera so cannot comment on that. It does not hold a charge as long as one would expect. Charger cable is ridiculously short and not as easy to plug in as I'd like. Never could tell which side was up so I marked the cable and the tablet and it's now easier.
The buttons are not very intuitive.  I've used it now for four months and still fumble to find the volume and power button. Because they are the same color as the frame, they are hard to see. Much better if they were a contrasting color.  The back button is invisible if you are in low light.  (why not have it lighted like on Samsung phones??) The home button is a hard button which makes no sense.
Wish there was a HDMI out because screen mirroring is difficult.

PROS:
FOR FUN: The picture is really sharp when you're playing games, watching Netflix, or perusing YouTube. The sound quality also took me by surprise. The first time I got on Pandora I was worried I blew out the speakers because it blasted so loudly. Thankfully, nope! This little thing just knows how to jam. It has better sound than my laptop with Beats Audio does (no joke). It loads websites and games quickly and I can easily move from program to program. Its light-weight, super easy to use, and the picture and sound quality are impressive.
FOR SCHOOL: I'm a senior in college, so I spend most of my time at school. Because the tablet is so lightweight and compact, I can carry this thing in my backpack every day without noticing the extra weight. I used to lug around my laptop, but it would make my shoulders ache by hour 2. I also purchased a protective cover with a wireless Bluetooth keyboard. Now, while the professor is lecturing, I can open up the slideshow on my tablet, and make my notes directly onto the slides. It is so easy and has made my note-taking so much faster! Not to mention, I can do research and work on essays in between classes. Productivity WIN!
I love, love, love this tablet!
CONS:
FOR FUN: The cameras seem a little lacking sometimes. When you're taking the picture, everything looks crystal clear (you can see pores galore). When you go back to look at the pictures, though, they seem a little grainy. I'm not sure why this is. It happens with both cameras (there's a camera on the back and a "selfie" camera on the front). The pictures are still of very good quality, and maybe I should be happy that my pores don't make an appearance, but the picture you view afterwards is not as sharp as the picture you thought you were taking.
FOR SCHOOL: I was unaware that Microsoft Office is NOT compatible with this tablet. I somehow missed the fact that Microsoft and Android were competitors. No worries, though! I have a very similar program downloaded. You can easily open up a Microsoft Office document (such as my professor's slideshows) and view/edit them with ease. You can even email the edited version back to your computer and view/edit it again on Microsoft Office. Again, I'm not sure why this is, but as long as I can get my work done with minimal headaches, I don't care.
Overall, I absolutely love this product! I am very impressed. It was worth every penny and has definitely been a beneficial addition to my life.
P.S. I got the Samsung Tab 4 because I have a Samsung S4 phone and I love them both! I have friends with the S5 and I really don't see the difference. The same goes for other tablets. In my opinion, the Tab 4 and the S4 are essentially cheaper for the same quality.

I have only had the tablet for 2 days but so far it has been everything that I have wanted it to be. The display is good to me, I know that it doesn't have the PPI as other higher end tablets but you get what you pay for and to me the screen is great for the money. I can't comment on the battery life of the device but I charged it 2 days ago and I still have 70% battery life left. With that being said I turn the device off when I get done using it. The camera isn't very good but I didn't buy it to take pictures, that is what a camera is for, so that doesn't really bother me. If you are wanting to take pictures then I wouldn't recommend this tablet. All in all, this is a great value buy if you want a device to browse the web and watch videos.

The one problem I have is I cannot watch Amazon Prime videos but I knew that when I bought the device. Hopefully the lollipop OS update will fix that problem.

I have no long term reliability experience with this model, but our previous Samsung tablet lasted over 3 years before being damaged. Hopefully this product will provide equally good reliability.

I've been thinking of a tablet for some time and when a deal came up with the Tab 4, I decided to jump on it.

Things I like:
Ease of use - yes!
  If you've owned any sort of touch screen, you won't have any issues with this. Wifi is an easy setup. Blu-tooth is an easy setup. Finding apps, adding screens, deleting screens, all super easy. I had to practice a little to do the hand sweep to capture a screen, and I was disappointed that my Samsung TV wasn't new enough to support screen mirroring (which would still work if I chose to buy another device), none of those are limitations on the tablet. The colors are bright and from what I can it is pretty customizable.
  It worked well with my Samsung TV, including the IR to use as a remote and even came with a handy app that let you view TV listings and change the channel when you chose "Watch this".
  It does a wonderful job at finding other devices and playing content from them. I had to do a little research to find out how to load my contacts, but it worked perfectly. A lot of it seems geared to google for sharing content, but I found when I input my gmail address, it synched everything up pretty well. If you do not use a gmail address, this might be a different experience. (I created a gmail account only because I was having issues with blogger, etc. I feel Google is a lot less intuitive to use than other programs.)
  I can't honestly tell if the tablet is watching my eyes, but since the screen hasn't gone blank when I've been reading, I assume it's working. Every now and then I would see a message saying it couldn't see my eyes. I haven't been able to mute the device just by holding my hand over it yet, but I haven't tried all that hard either.
  It is for the most part a very fluid and intuitive interface. I have had one or two things I had to go to YouTube to figure out how to do, but this has been rare.
  The camera takes good pictures both front and back.
  I like the double functionality of the buttons and the 2 trays. The top is highly customizable, but geared mostly towards settings. The side tray or the "split screen" tray does split screen very well. This is saying something. It's easy to use, to change the size of the 2 screens and to switch them, close them, etc. It doesn't require any head scratching which is saying something in these kinds of interfaces.

Things I don't like:
  There's not much I don't like to be honest, but here goes. . . .
  The split screen feature which is much heralded does have some limitations. First, you can only split the screen from the split screen tray, and you can't add other programs to that tray. For example, if I want to start chrome and use the memo app at the same time, I can split the screen. However, if I'm looking at Chrome and I want to use the calculator, nope. The calculator isn't in the tray and can't be added. Oh well, that's not such a big deal, because I can easily minimize one to use the other.
  Programs don't really close. Unless the program has an "exit", you'll hit the "home" key to exit, but when you check the taskbar, the program is still technically there. I'm fairly certain it's still using memory and therefore battery power. It would be nice to be able to close the program / window without having to take this extra step. The luxury of the little "x" you see in Windows is missing.
  The tablet comes ready to view pictures, music and videos from devices other than your tablet (for example your PC). However, I couldn't do a simple file transfer. Even the "my files" application that came installed couldn't manage this. It will play movies on your PC (on the screen of the tablet), but it doesn't actually transfer the files. I had to download Airdroid to transfer certain files.
I love my Galaxy Tab 4.  It's definitely faster than the Tab 3 I previously owned, and the battery seems to last a long time.

A little slower than I wish but the screen is great and I was pleasantly surprised by the speakers in it (I guess I wasn't really expecting anything). The sound quality is better than expected.
The size is great, it isn't too heavy.
The interface is pretty intuitive - if you want more options for whatever you're looking at, press and hold your finger over the item, that simple. It's easy to navigate.
Cameras are useless in low light but satisfactory in sunlight.
No issues with Hancom Office - you can edit and create documents. I look forward to this replacing my laptop as my homework machine, drastically reducing the weight of my backpack. I still need to find a reliable bluetooth keyboard though.
It seems like the touch screen registering finger strokes might be slightly off, like I click one spot and it thinks I clicked slightly up and to the left of where I did. Slightly. Or perhaps it's the number of pixels it recognizes as a finger stroke that messes with it. I'm not sure. That really is only noticeable if paying strict attention though.
Battery has been great. I use it pretty much all day with lots of internet and some gaming mixed in and the lowest I've gotten it is 20%.
The expandable memory is my favorite thing about it. I love being able to have multiple memory (media) cards. One for music, one for movies, I always keep the other one in my backpack (Samsung has a sweet warranty on their microSD cards).
Haven't had a chance yet to experiment with the GPS function of it when no wifi is available, but with google maps the wifi will tell me what part of what room of what building I'm in on campus (is that just because it knows where the modem/router is?)
Overall, I'd recommend it. It's way less expensive than an iPad Air, or the new Tab S but it still gets the job done with room to spare. I'm very happy I decided last minute to not fork out the $599 to get the iPad Air 2 and went with the $259 Tab 4 instead.

The good: light weight, sufficient screen resolution, fluid performance

The bad: the battery went dead after only 4 months of use. I opened the device to try finding/fixing problems, and found the assembly to be very delicate. In particular, the battery and memory chips are wrapped below the cables for LCD and touch screen. To replace the battery, you will have to remove these cables, which is not a problem by itself. The real problem comes when you have to put the cables back; these cables are very thin and have to be very precisely aligned with the sockets for the device to function; for more information see this webpage: https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/Samsung+Galaxy+Tab+10.1+Battery+Replacement/18432

I am the kind who like to open things up, but my suggestion for this one, if any problem manifests, is to send it back (if within warranty) directly without trying anything yourself.

I got the 10.1" and it reminds me of the mini laptop I used to own, but a lot lighter in weight.  I purchased it to check my email at night before going to bed. I have been a tablet owner for many years, and have owned several different ones.  I started years ago with a Motorola Xoom, then upgraded to a Galaxy Tab and then to Tab 2.  I now own a Galaxy Note 2014.  This purchase in particular was for my mother-in-law who has been my new baby's nanny while my wife has gone back to work.  I LOVE Samsung products, and this tablet certainly does not disappoint.  It is very fast, and has the bells and whistles that make Samsung products great.

The parts of this that made me ding it back to a 4-star though are more nit picky.  First, my mother-in-law was planning to use this to also take pictures.  That would have been great, except this tablet does NOT have a flash on it.  I was extremely surprised, as the previous Tab's had flashes.  Had I known this, I would not have made this purchase.  I believe on these later models, they did away with this option and have put that onto the Pro version.  In the end though, it is my fault for not double checking on this prior to purchasing.  The other gripe I have, is the limitation of drive space.  Me personally, I watch videos and such while commuting on a train and space is very important.  However, since there is a microSD port, this is not of too big a concern for me.

All in all, this is a very fast and good tablet.  Just be sure that it fits your needs well. If you intend to take pictures with it, I would recommend upgrading to the Pro version as it has the flash (which you will certainly miss if you take pictures).  If you are just wanting to play games, surf the web and do email, then this tablet is an excellent option.

As with all my reviews, feel free to ask any questions and I will be happy to answer them.

After using my 1st gen Nexus 7 for two years, I wanted a tab with a larger screen and decided on the Galaxy Tab 4 10.1, after a quick review of what is currently available. I've used it for a couple of days and have to say I'm a bit underwhelmed. It's not a bad unit, but it can be a bit laggy at times and the screen is rather disappointing. It's not as sharp and the colors not as accurate as I was hoping for. Although it's noticeable mainly with videos, text is also not as sharp as I'd like, which can lead to eye strain. The pixel density is around 130 ppi which is pretty low, and jagged edges and text anti-aliasing are visible (depends to a degree how far away from your eyes you hold the tab). Although the resolution is touted as 'high resolution' (which is technically correct in HD TV or desktop monitor terms), for a tablet this is misleading due to the close viewing distance. I also feel that the price is a bit high for what you get in terms of specs and build quality.

My expectations in a tablet have been raised since getting my Galaxy S4 smartphone, which has a razor sharp, high contrast, super-amoled screen (w/ 440 ppi pixel density) and faster processor compared to this tablet. Using this tab feels like a step backwards in comparison. I've also realized that the 10" form factor isn't ideal for my uses. I'll be returning mine and will order either a Galaxy Pro 8.4 or Galaxy S 8.4 to replace it. The 8.4" form factor is significantly lighter and much more comfortable to use, while the higher res screen should more than offset the size advantage of the 10.1" w/ lower res. I'd consider an ipad mini /w retina display, but the lack of expandable storage is a deal breaker. All of these alternatives have pixel densities above 300 ppi, which is supposedly the point at which individual pixels are indistinguishable to the naked eye at the typical tablet viewing distance (though some argue that even 300 is still far too low).

IMO, spending a bit more for a superior tablet is well worth it, considering the hundreds of hours I'll be staring at it for the next three years or so. But then again, I'm not so young anymore and my eyes aren't as good as they used to be. If I were in my teens or 20's, or on a tight budget, I'd probably just keep this one ;)

Update 9/30/14: The Galaxy Tab Pro, which is superior to this model (Tab 4), is now on sale at BB and the price is just slightly higher than the Tab 4. If you can get one before they sell out, it's a far better choice than the Tab 4.

I never write reviews on products, but I have to on this one....I had my tablet for about 6 months and it stopped charging. I went through the proper channels to send it off to get repaired by Samsung as there is a 1 yr warranty on the tablet. Once they got my tablet it took them 2 weeks to get back to me to tell me they weren't going to honor the warranty because there was a scratch on it (not even near where you connect the charger), but I could pay the $199 out of warranty fee to get it repaired or have them send it back to me not fixed. What does a scratch have to do with it not charging??? They wouldn't tell me why it wasn't charging; if it was the battery or the connection on the tablet, just that I had to pay them $199 to have it fixed. This is what the email said, "In order to repair the unit, we would need an out of warranty fee of $199.00. If you would prefer not to pay this fee, we can ship the unit back to you unrepaired at no cost." I will NOT pay this "out of warranty fee" nor will I EVER purchase another Samsung product again! I would not recommend this to anyone as they do not honor their warranty! My girlfriend had the same problem with her's too and they refused to honor her warranty as well!

I did a lot of research finding a tablet that fits my needs.  I wanted something to take to classes so that I could keep my laptop at home; I had my laptop stolen once.

This is a great tablet, but there are two features that made me return it.

1. No ambient light sensor.  I was shocked to find it didn't have one.  Maybe Samsung had a good reason, but I found it a bit of a hassle to change the light settings all the time.
2. Charging port on the longer side of the tablet, rather than the shorter side.  The 7" and the 8" both have the charging ports on the side, making it easy to charge while in a standing case.  This is not possible with the 10" as the port is on the "longer side" aka, the bottom.
